item.title: Worker Day | Detained in the first protest in six years
item.description:
Police detained on the day of the worker a man protesting the number of migrant workers in Macao, invoking violation of the Law of Meeting and Manifestation Law. Also the Power of the People's Association canceled a demonstration, after the authorities suggested not wanting to debut the application of the law on the security of the state
On May 1, Labor Day, a man was arrested by agents of the Public Security Police Corps (CPSP) when manifested against the importation of non-resident workers. CPSP source told Lusa that man showed 'slogans' (slogans) and chanting chants to demand the reduction of migrant workers at the door of the management services for the first public protest on May 1, 2019, before the COVID-19 pandemic. A video that circulates on social networks shows the man to put eight sheets of paper on the floor with the message “Government, cut on migrant workers! next to the flags of Macao and China. The Mishes was employed at the end of March nearly 183,400,000 migrant workers, still far from the maximum peak of 196,538, hit in late 2019 at the beginning of the pandemic. According to the CPSP, the agents made repeated warnings for violations of the Law of Meeting and Manifestation Law, but the man refused to obey and was taken to the squad to be identified. During the pandemic, security forces refused to approve the course of any protest, invoking reasons for “order and safety” or public health. Authorities raised anti-standard restrictions at the end of 2023, but the protests did not return to the city streets. These prohibitions arrived at the UN Human Rights Committee, which in 2022 evaluated "an increasing number of information of improper restrictions on the exercise of freedom of peaceful manifestations." It would be a pity The Power of the People's Association, which also requires a reduction in the number of migrant workers, canceled a manifestation planned for Labor Day due to “police pressure,” the All About Macau newspaper reported on Thursday. The association said it expected 20,000 participants, but canceled the event after police claimed that it could violate the National Security Act. Group President Lam Weng Ioi said he filed a formal statement of demonstration in April, but was summoned to repeated police meetings to "analyze the situation" and "avoid uncontrollable circumstances." Lam claimed that the authorities raised questions about the “joint responsibility of the organizers” and the warning of “National Security”, which led the group to present a written appeal. Speaking to the Macao TDM channel, the associative leader said that the authorities advanced various possibilities such as the intervention of “people with bad intentions” that could take advantage of the activities to create confusion, or from participants who could compromise public order, and that the association would be responsible for any disorder or irregularity. "We said we were going to have a special team to maintain order. However, police officers doubted our ability to control local order," Lam Weng Ioi told public television. The authorities also suggested that the manifestation of Labor Day could infringe national security laws. "It was mentioned, indirectly, (the violation of) law on the defense of state security. I was told that there was no detention, previously, based on this law and that they did not want us to be the first case of law on the defense of state security," said the president of the Power of the People Association. The PSP confirmed that it had received a statement notification for May 1, but said the organizer removed it voluntarily. Au Kam San disagree Following the case of the individual detained for protesting the importation of non-resident workers to Macao, at the gates of the management of services for labor affairs, on the day of the worker, former deputy Au Kam San argued that the act concerned was not a demonstration. As such, the action of public security police officers was not correct. In a Facebook publication, the former deputy disagreed with the police argument that the subject had not prior notice to the demonstration because he is only an individual and a small-scale protest and that the concept of manifestation depends on the number of people involved. Even so, it pointed out that there is no necessary authorization for notice of demonstration, a fundamental right provided for in the basic law of masters.

item.title: Public function | Ten over-the-weekend in 2026
item.description:
Next year, civil service workers will have 10 weekends with at least three days of rest, and another period of three and a half days of rest, at the time of Lunar New Year celebrations
The civil service will enjoy a total of ten weekends in 2026, between point tolerances, compensatory rest days and holidays. The government's holiday calendar and rest days defined by the government for next year was released on Wednesday through an order published in the official bulletin. The first prolonged weekend arrives in April, between the 3rd, a Friday, in which the death of Christ is marked, and the 7th, a Tuesday, used to compensate for the fact of the Cheng Ming holiday, coinciding with Sunday. In the midst of these five days also Monday, the 6th, is defined as a period of compensatory rest, due to the eve of the resurrection of Christ, which is marked on Saturday, April 4. The second prolonged weekend takes place in early May, between the 1st, a Friday, in which the Labor Day is marked, and Sunday May 3. In the fifth month of the year there is a second last weekend of three days for the civil service, since Buddha day coincides with Sunday May 24, so May 25, Monday, was declared a period of compensatory rest. The last long rest in the first half of the year takes place in June, between 19 and 21, since the day related to Tung NG (dragon boat) coincides with this Friday. A beautiful few, start Between July and August there is no holiday next year. However, from September every month they have at least one prolonged weekend for the civil service. The first one happens in September, due to the fact that Sam Hou Fai had defined Monday, the 28th, as a period of compensatory rest, since the holiday of the lunar cake is marked on September 26, a Saturday. Another rest period comes with the establishment of the Popular Republic of China and its celebrations, a new prolonged weekend, this time of four days. The day of implementation is marked on October 1, a Thursday, and since the next day is also a holiday, workers can rest from Thursday to Sunday. Still in October, the day of the Ancestor (Chong Yeong) worship coincides with Sunday the 18th, so the following Monday was defined as a new compensatory rest day. The first weekend of November is equally prolonged due to the fact that the day of all coincides with Monday, the 2nd. The latest weekend will take place on the date of establishment of the MSAR. December 20th coincides with a Sunday, so Monday, the 21st, was defined as compensatory rest day. This day follows the winter solstice holiday, which contributes to a four-day rest. After working on December 23rd, there are two more days of holidays, December 24 and 25, due to Christmas, which glue with the weekend of 26 and 27 December, in another period of rest of four days. Other holidays In addition to prolonged weekends, the civil service will enjoy a period of rest of three and a half days, during the celebrations of the Lunar New Year. The three holidays of this festivity take place between February 17 and 19, but the government has decreed half a day of tolerance from February 16. As traditionally it happens, the first holiday is January 1, the day of universal fraternity. Also December 8th is holiday day, day of the Immaculate Conception. In addition to these days, the executive also defined December 31 as a day tolerance day in the afternoon. In total there are 20 holidays, of which six result in compensation days and two time tolerances in the afternoon.

item.title: Song Pek Kei suggests construction of electrical center in hengqin

The discussion at AL about the electric supply was launched by Deputy Ho Ion Sang, recalling the energy blackout that affected, on Monday, Portugal and Spain. One situation, he considered Ho, which "draws attention to the safety of electricity supply in Macao, where more than 90 percent of electricity is provided inside China." The deputy recalled the “large interruption” in the electricity distribution in 2017, due to the passage of the hat. “Is there a response mechanism or not?” Asked the parliamentarian. All in conformity The Secretary for Transport and Public Works, Raymond Tam Vai Man, noted that “there are three cables”, originating in the interior of China, “for the transfer of electricity to Macao”, being a room in the plans of the authorities. item.title: Saint Valentine's Day in the Czech Republic
item.description: In Macao, many people know that May 1st is Labor Day and is an official holiday. The same takes place in mainland China, marking May 1st the beginning of a long holiday. However, few know that in the Republic checked May 1st is the "Day of St. Valentine". On Valentine's Day, Czech lovers follow tradition and kiss under the cherry trees, singing songs to love. And the kiss why? According to Czech folklore, if a girl is not kissed under a cherry tree on St. Valentine's day, she will "wither" next year, losing "youth and charm." Therefore, a kiss means "protection and blessings." And what is “protection in love”? In mid -2015, Sean Lau, the winner of the Hong Kong's best actor's best actor award for his work in the movie “Overheard 3”, presented the “Space Nave Theory”. He used a simple phrase to show how his wife Amy Kwok protected him: “When I enter a spaceship and travel anywhere in the universe, you always find a way to bring me back to Earth safely.” The meaning of this phrase is simple and clear. If you are where you are, face what to face, you always bring me back safely. You are always by my side, making me be loved, hot, happy and in peace. Apart from the “spacecraft theory”, there is another sean Lau phrase that is part of the “passionate quotes for my wife”: "One day you no longer want to love love, you just want someone who doesn't leave you." Does true love require two people to stay together? In March 2025, news was released in Taiwan, China, saying that a woman had published an online article, where she said she had a boyfriend six years ago, but eventually found out that he was getting married to another. And this happened because her boyfriend loved her so much and didn't want her to go through the suffering caused by her relationship with her mother-in-law, so she decided to marry a woman from whom her parents liked, but he didn't like and assured his girlfriend that his "relationship" would not be affected. After marrying another woman, she would date forever with her beloved. Love implies "protection and blessings." Is it in favor of the “spacecraft theory” or “Nora/mother -in -law theory”? What are "blessings"? In Taiwan, China, the host of the television program “Yu Meiren”, (Yu Yunjie) had no contact with her in -laws for a long time. Once went to court due to a disagreement between mother and husband. Finally, the judge stated that his 16 -year marriage had come to an end. Later, Yu Meiren has lost a lot of weight, but now it is more beautiful than before and at his disposal has changed. She stated: "The French believe that in love we should accept those who come and we should not retain those who want to leave. 'When love happens, we must be ourselves, follow our hearts and act without schemes. When love is over, we must respect the other and not try to arrest or force it, which means that" letting out is the best of blessings. " Do you agree with the phrase “letting go is the best of blessings, the blessing is the best relief”? Hong Kong Cine Cine Cine Cenilia Cheung once expressed some disappointment after the divorce: "In love there is only one thing that can hurt us, it is the unwillingness. When we cannot live with ourselves, we inflicted pain." Perhaps that “protection and blessings” have different meanings for each person, but for me, "I have to say this only once. After all these years, I still love you." item.title: Trump and the politicization of time and climate
item.description: The disagreements between Trump and meteorologists are not new. Already in the first administration he directed by him there were disagreements that echoed in the US and international press. Its intrusion in predictions about the evolution of Hurricane Dorian in 2019 caused the “American Meteorological Society” (AMS) and the “National Weather Association (NWA) to diffuse a joint statement that there would likely be damage caused by the weather in the state of Alabama, as Mr. Trump had vatified. Perhaps for this reason, the then president of the United States of America may have been hating meteorologists and, by dragging, climatologists. Note that being a meteorologist is different from being a climatologist. The meteorologist, among other functions, analyzes the current time and foresees its evolution for the following days, while the climatologist studies the average time of a particular region, or even on a global scale and, using computational models, prepares antevisions of what could happen in the medium and long term, and the period is covered to reach dozens of years. While characterizing time in a particular place or region it is necessary to know the various weather parameters (temperature, moisture, atmospheric pressure, wind, cloudiness, precipitation, etc.) at a given time or a short period, to characterize the climate with the predominant time for relatively long periods. According to the world weather organization, this period should be at least thirty years. Returning to the different between Trump and meteorologists, their interpretation in the functions of these professionals and the institutions where they develop their activity may be the reflection of their vengeful character or by the fact that it is simple, not being able to love the storms (or intensify them), or determine when phenomena such as El-Niño, La Niña, monsoons, etc., should be beginning or ends. On the other hand, with the help of the oligarchs that have gained power in the US, the second country that most emits greenhouse gases (GHG) can certainly influence the climate. As? You can ask. The answer is simple. It is proven that the combustion of fossil fuels (oil, natural gas and mineral coal) is largely responsible for increasing the concentration of GHGs in the atmosphere, the main cause of climate change since the beginning of the industrial age. Since Trump is reversing all laws in the US that advocates the reduction of the use of such fuels, the gee concentration will continue to increase significantly, which will contribute to accentuating these changes. The weather will probably resent the measures being taken, including the cutting of funds in all that relates to the study of climate change and their consequences. The intensification of “drill, baby, drill”, as he likes to repeat, will contribute to the imbalance that the climate is being targeted. The various components of the climate system, especially the atmosphere, the biosphere, the cryiosfera and the hydrosphere will continue to suffer the consequences of the non -accepting of the recommendations of thousands of scientists, through the IPCC, the Kyoto Protocol, the 29 COP (Conference of the Parties) agreement, etc. The atmosphere is increasingly impregnated with GEE, the biosphere is degrading with the increasingly frequent forest fires; The oceans increase in salinity caused by acid rain and the absorption of carbon dioxide; The Criosfera ice fusion rate is increasing, which has the most serious consequence of increasing sea level. The unknown with which the current US administration deals with the issues associated with the climate and environment is such that, on the Official “Website” of the White House, an “Executive Order” with the title “Reinvigoring America’s Beautiful Clean Coal Industry and Amending Order 14241”, dated April 8, 2025, in which one of the most polluting industries is designated by “Beautiful Industry Charcoal clean". Megha Satyanarayana, chief editor of the opinion section of Scientific American magazine, recently asked "Why is the Trump Administration Politicizing Weather?" The ongoing dismissal of scientists who develop their activity in the National Weather Service (NWS), department of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA), is part of this effort to end the discordant voices of their policy. In its painful view, Trump administration does not see that, putting into practice this project, it is limiting the efficiency of an institution that has undoubtedly contributed to the safeguarding of lives and goods in a highly efficient way. Based on the information from the weather stations, the weather satellites and communications, the radars, the weather and climate forecast models, weather services are contributing to the prosperity of the countries where they operate. Millions of lives have been saved thanks to meteorological warning systems, based on which alerts about the evolution and approach of highly serious phenomena are prepared, such as tropical and extractic cyclones. An example of what the absence of weather information can cause, was what happened on September 8, 1900, when a hurricane hit the South Coast near Galveston in the Gulf of Mexico (Sorry Mr. Trump). item.title: Happiness in Macau
item.description: Executive Chief Sam Hoi-Fai has just announced the government lines for 2025, which contains several highlights: first, 10,000 patacas pecuniary checks continue to be distributed. Second, the pension for the elderly will increase from 3,740 monthly patacas to 3,900, the elderly subsidy increases from 9,000 annual patacas to 10,000, the voucher of the health care reimbursement program rises from 600 patacas to 700. In addition, the childhood assistance in the amount of 1,500 monthly patacas was first atrible. Several social support increased, but we didn't all listed them here. Social support has increased, allowing the beneficiaries to have a better life, which makes everyone happy. Did the government increase several subsidies just because residents so demanded it? The answer is, of course not. Social security systems have created a diverse support network for residents. Increasing benefits increases everyone's feeling of safety: pensions function like a hot blanket, the health system is solid support and the unprotected assistance program is like a long river in helping the weaker. These systems are not dehumanized legal provisions, but the master walls of peace of mind. These master walls try to ensure that everyone can get the essentials. Happiness is not only due to the social security system, but also from people's interactions. This kind of interaction gives us that happiness is waiting for us, and that we can find it for ourselves. In some old tea houses, we often see customers to talk to owners for hours. Owners know that Uncle Zhang wants three parts of sugar and that Aunt Li avoids chopped green onions and prepare the food and drinks in time, waiting for old friends. Do these owners prepare food for the purpose of making money? Of course. What they want is exactly the same as customers. Owners hope to be happy as well as their customers. They all care about each other. The small area of ​​Macau shortens our way away. If we take more than 15 minutes to drive to our destination, we say we go away. But can we think this issue from another perspective? Precisely because Macau is not big, when we left home for a day, the sun still shines when we arrive at Hac Sa Beach. A half-hour car trip drives us away from the confusion and the noise and we give us to a quiet beach. We left footprints in the sand, ate pears and smelled the salty smell of the sea. At night we can look at the stars and talk to the loved one. Another advantage of a small town is that it is full of human warmth. In the morning, during the end-time transport, grandparents who do not know each other, sitting on several lines, tell stories about their grandchildren turning back and forth. These energetic conversations cross the noise and reach everyone's ears. The front row student turns his head with apparent impatience, but the corners of his mouth have an uncomfortable smile - Macao, even when there are "discussions", is a charming region full of human warmth. Macao people also have their serene rituals. One day I saw a man run at a stadium in Macau. He told me that running alone, with no one against who to compete, made him feel extremely comfortable and needed no one else. After running, he let the water wash his fatigue. When he returned the house, he took a shower and relaxed completely. There are numerous interpretations of happiness in Macau: it is the usual soup that the owner of a restaurant prepares for old customers. These are the sweet words of lovers on the beach of Hac Sa. It is the sudden explosion of laughter in the bus. It's someone who takes a bath at home. In the 1980s, the song “Happy” was written by singer Sam Hui. I put below part of the letter: "Happiness is waiting every minute, as long as you know where you find it." “Happiness is to look for the stars in the sky, happiness is the foot footprints on the beach of memories.” "Happiness is to leave the city's dust behind. Happiness is to go home and take a bath of immersion." I like to travel. Also, when I have time, I prefer to have a drink. "Happiness is to hum a beautiful song, a afternoon newspaper and a glass of champagne." The government lines have instituted “the childhood assistance allowance”, allowing parents to receive a value of 1,500 patacas since their child is born until they reach the age of three years. To raise a child we need millions of dollars and 1,500 monthly patacas are not surely enough. However, the message that childhood assistance subsidy brings us is not whether 1,500 patacas is sufficient to raise a child, but to allow parents to receive support to raise their children, reducing their financial pressure and allowing them to enjoy “family happiness”. And isn't it “family happiness” a kind of happiness? “Happiness is the disposition that my good woman gives me and happiness is the affectionate kiss that my son gives me. If we can share our happiness with others, we will have a“ happy world ”, it is a world that everyone pursues and longs for. item.title: Taipa Village | Frank Lei Exhibition on Exhibition from Tomorrow
item.description:
The Vila da Taipa Cultural Association presents tomorrow “Frank Law: Cuba 92”, an exhibition of photography dedicated to the artist based in Macau and deceased in 2022. Here is the opportunity to see images of Cuba 1992, never before shown, in which it is a tribute to Frank Lei
He was born in Beijing and since he had lived in Macau. Frank Law, a man dedicated to the arts and photography, died in 2022 victim of prolonged illness, but is now entitled to a tribute through the display of his work. This is the exhibition “Frank Law: Cuba 92”, evident from tomorrow, and until July 9, at the Vila da Taipa Cultural Association, with unpublished images captured by law in Cuba, in 1992. According to a statement from the organization, Frank Lei passed away leaving "a vast set of photographic works that remain little known to the general public." In this way, this show was born of the joint effort of family, friends and, above all, Alan Ieong Chon Weng, one of the founders of the Dialect group, dedicated to photography. “In 1992, Frank Law first traveled to Cuba, visiting not only the capital, Havana, but also Santiago de Cuba, in the eastern part of the island, demonstrating his deep attention and exploitation of Cuban culture and community,” says the organization, not only the artist launched not only an exhibition, but also a book with these images, with the name “Cuba Cuba”. This project included “selected works, filmed in color diaper”, constituting “the core of a narrative that presented a vibrant and living impression of the island nation”. In addition, Frank Law files on Cuba "include a set of unpublished black and white photographs, monochrome images that capture everyday life and the emotions of the Cuban people from a more subtle and contained perspective." Now, with this new exhibition, the display of these black and white images never revealed to the public "offers a new window in time and space, allowing the viewer to know the island's landscape that so much captivated the soul of Frank and which constitutes the invisible side of his trip to Cuba." "The initiative to bring to light these works is a recognition of the relevance of photography to document human realities and the circumstances of people's lives. Spectators have the opportunity to revisit Frank's works not only, but also to embrace the emotions they evoke about the survival of a society and a country as a Cuba," the organization highlights. Quoted by the same note, João Ó, architect and president of the Vila da Taipa Cultural Association, said it was “an honor to collaborate with Dialect to present this unprecedented collection of black and white photographs of Frank to Cuba's trip”. “The selection of photographs pays tribute to Frank's singular dedication to artistic and cultural creative industries over the years and shows the passion for Cuban culture that has impregnated his heart and soul,” he adds. A man from Macau Born in Beijing, Frank came to Macau at the age of ten. He graduated in journalism and worked as a reporter in the newspaper or Mun after the degree. Then he fell in love with the French cinema of the so-called “New Vacancy”, having gone to Paris to study cinema and video at the University of Sorbonne in 1991. In the same year, he was admitted at École Nationale Supérieure des Arts Décoratifs de Paris, where he studied photography, and also won the first award in the International Photography Contest “Life on the Street”, organized by the Musée de La Photographie. Frank Lei exposed his images on the Grand Palais de Paris, being part of the permanent collection of Musée de la photographie. In 1992, Frank traveled to Cuba to work in artistic projects and even waved to President Fidel Castro, highlights the organization of the exhibition. He then returned to Macau, where he taught at the School of Arts of the Macao Polytechnic Institute, today Macao Polytechnic University. “Cinema, photography, music and literature were Frank's passions throughout his life and, right after his return to Macau, embraced Buddhism, bringing a simple and vegetarian lifestyle,” he says. Frank Law was exposing his work in France, Macau and Hong Kong. In 1995, he founded the Macao Pedra Commune Artistic Group. In 2004, two years after his first exhibition about Cuba, it was found that Frank suffered from cancer in his brain. After treatment, he returned to the then Macao Polytechnic Institute, continued to work in the ox warehouse and began drawing extensively during his recovery. In 2006, he published the photographic anthology “walking and observing” with Pin-to Books. He continued to photograph and create paintings, organizing individual exhibitions and small painting exhibitions, and traveled to New York, South Korea and France for exchanges and photographic shows. In early 2017, Frank was invited to Strasbourg Art Photography, a permanent festival of photography in France, for a photographic exhibition and an exchange. After the disease, Frank Law died on May 18, 2022.

Venice prepares to host another edition of the biennial dedicated to architecture, this time the 19th. The show features Iwan Baan, a winning architecture photographer of a “Golden Lion” in one of the biennial editions. According to the same note as IC, Iwan Baan "captures pieces of memories and the contemporary vitality of Macao's urban spaces through his highly narrative images." In this Macao space at the Biennial, their images promise “dialogue with architectural models and outdoor facilities created by teachers and students from the Faculty of Architecture of the China Academy of Arts and the Faculty of Architecture and Design at the University of São José de Macau”. Thus, it is allowed the public to “feel the unique charm of Macau amid the mix of history and modernity”. Team work The 19th edition of the International Architecture Exhibition - Venice Biennial has as its theme “intelligent, natural, artificial, collective”, thus reflecting “on the role of architecture in the process of globalization”. Curators Wang Shu and Lu Wenyu are architects and educators who have been working in the contemporary Chinese architecture field for over twenty years. The Faculty of Architecture of the China Academy of Arts in 2003 were co-founded, and was “committed to reconstructing the study and practice of contemporary architecture of China”. Wang Shu is currently a director of the China Academy of Arts Faculty of Architecture, having surprised the world of architecture with the work “Garden of Tiles”, aired in the first China pavilion at the Venice Architecture Biennial. Lu Wenyu was a member of the Jury of the UNESCO Asia Pacific Prize for the conservation of cultural heritage, having received the honorary prize of the Venice Biennial. Regarding the names participating in this project, Iwan Baan is a Dutch photographer “known for its capture of images of life and interaction inside buildings”, this time, with teachers and students from the Macao and China architecture colleges. The idea was “to form an interdisciplinary creative team”, presenting “a fantastic interpretation of the multicultural integration” of the territory, showing the world “the cultural inclusion of Macao through its architectural language”. The exhibition “Parallel Worlds” will be available at the “Arsenalle” space, in Campo Della Tana, Castello, in the city of Venice.

item.title: Banking | Profits shoot 44.8% in the first quarter
item.description:

Macao banks made a profit of 4.01 billion patacas by 2024, a drop of 21.3 percent and the lowest value since 2010, especially due to the fall of interest margin. The loans, the main source of revenue of the banking worldwide, decreased 4.7 percent in the last 12 months, setting 1.02 billion of patacas in late March. In March, overdue loans represented 5.5 percent of Macao banks loans, more than 1.3 percentage points than in the same month as 2023. A percentage that reaches 6.7 percent in the case of credit to institutions or individuals outside the Chinese region. item.title: GDP | Macao with the first reduction since the end of 2022
item.description:
The increase of tourists in the territory was not reflected in consumption in the first three months of the year. The drop in gross domestic product compared to the same period does not yet take into account the potential effects of the trade war
Macao's economy shrank 1.3 percent in homologous terms in the first quarter of this year, the first fall since the end of 2022, when the region began to raise restrictions due to the pandemic, was announced on Friday. Between January and March, Macao Gross Domestic Product (GDP) reached 99.78 billion Patacas, the Board of Statistics and Census Services (DSEC) said. In a statement issued on Friday, DSEC pointed out as reasons for the decrease the “relatively high comparison base” of the first quarter of 2024 and the “change of visitor consumption pattern”. The economic benefit of tourist services - the sector that dominates Macau's economy - fell 3.8 percent, although the first trimester was the second best ever about the number of visitors. According to official data, Macau received 9.86 million tourists by March 11.1 percent than in the same period of 2024, but visitors have spent less in the city. The latest data point to a 14.6 percent drop in tourist per capita expense over the last year. Macao's economy grew 23 percent in the first quarter of 2024 and ended the year up 8.8 percent. The last time the region's GDP was at the end of 2022. Continental China-by far the main source of visitors from Macau-began to gradually raise all restrictions due to Covid-19 pandemic in mid-December 2022. “Stable looking” Despite the reduction of GDP, DSEC stressed that internal demand was “relatively stable”, with private investment rising 7.8 percent, government expenses increasing 1 percent and private consumption to grow 0.6 percent. On April 10, the University of Macao (one) reviewed the forecast for economic growth in the region, in part due to the potential impact of the tariffs imposed by the United States on the confidence of Chinese tourists. The Macao Study Center and the department of Economics of UM predict that the territory GDP rose 6.8 percent, 1.1 percentage points than in the previous forecast, made in January. Project coordinator and economist Kwan Fung said the low review is due to the decline in the consumption of visitors and the "US world tariffs," something that "has an indirect impact on Macao's economy." UM Economy Department professor said the fares will "affect the growth of all economies, especially the consumption of tourists in the interior of China." In early March, the Financial Notation Agency Fitch predicted that the growth of Macau's economy will slow down to 6.9 percent this year, due to a “slower” recovery of tourism and game. "However, a sharp slowdown in the Chinese economy, such as the substantial increases in US tariffs, and a strong yuan devaluation pose negative risks to Macao's perspectives," said Fitch.

item.title: Hong Kong | HRW requires release from activist father
item.description: The Human Rights Watch organization yesterday called for the release of the Hong Kong Anna Kwok human rights defender, detained in late April, and denounced the harassment of territory authorities to family members of activists. Hong Kong police detained the father of the rooted activist in the United States Anna Kwok, "and accused him of a national security crime," he began writing in a statement to Human Rights Watch (HRW), which requires the release of Kwok Yin-Sang and being "immediately withdrawn all charges." Hong Kong National Security Police announced on Friday the arrest of Kwok's father and brother, accused of trying to manage the activist's financial resources. According to police sources, this is the first time that the controversial national security law is applied that criminalizes assistance to “designated fugitives” in the management of the assets that hold. According to the EFE agency on Friday, Hong Kong authorities detained 35 and 68-yearly Anna Kwok's brother and father in Tseung Kwan O district on April 30 and accused the last of trying to raise funds from an insurance policy on the name of their daughter, presenting documents with allegedly false signatures. Anna Kwok, 28, lives in the United States and is a executive director of the Hong Kong Democracy Council, a US -based non -profit organization and created to promote freedoms in China. Although the father remains detained, his brother, an employee of the insurance company who manages Kwok's policies, was released under bail and is being investigated for possible abuse of office to facilitate the operation. Also according to EFE, the authorities have reiterated the warning that anyone who collaborates with “designated fugitives” incurs heavy penalties that can go up to seven years in prison.

item.title: Xanana Gusmão asks Timorese to encourage children to learn Portuguese
item.description: The Prime Minister of Timor-Leste, Xanana Gusmão, asked yesterday from parents to encourage children to learn Portuguese, a language that is part of the Timorese identity. "To fathers and mothers, I ask you to encourage your children to learn Portuguese, because, according to our history, it is the Portuguese that represents our identity, not English, nor Indonesian," said Xanana Gusmão. The Timorese Prime Minister spoke at the Government Palace under the celebrations of the World Day of Portuguese Language and the Culture of the Community of Portuguese-Speaking Countries (CPLP) during an activity made by the Portuguese Embassy and the Timorese Ministry of Education, who gathered hundreds of students from the Learning and Formation Center (Cafe Schools), in a march to deliver books to Gusmão Xanana. The head of the Timorese government recalled that for 24 years of Indonesian occupation, the Portuguese language was not taught and that it is necessary to overcome that inheritance so that Timor-Leste does not risk being absorbed again by Indonesia. “Students should study and learn the Portuguese language, because it is the identity of Timor-Leste,” said Xanana Gusmão to the Timorese students, also asking them to thank Portugal for sending teachers. "For us, Timorese, teaching Portuguese is a little difficult, because we do not master the language well, but we thank the Portuguese government for the creation of coffee schools," he added. The project of the Learning and School Training Center or the Cafe Schools began in 2014, and is already present in the 12 Timorese Municipalities and the Oedusi Enclave, on the Indonesian side of Timor Island, and the extent of those educational establishments for administrative posts in the country is also foreseen. Those schools, where classes are given by Portuguese and Timorese teachers, are currently attended by more than 11,100 Timorese students. Cafe has two large pillars, namely quality teaching in the classroom and the complementary training of Timorese teachers. Share the future In those schools, the classes are taught in Portuguese, but students also have classes in Tetum, the second official language of Timor-Leste. Education Minister Dulce Soares stressed that Portuguese is a language of “affection, knowledge and future”. “This is where we share stories, build learning and open new ways,” said Dulce Soares, stressing that the Portuguese language represents diversity, creativity, identity and hope. "Promoting the Portuguese language is also to promote education, cooperation and development," he added. World CPLP World Language and Culture Day was also marked in the National Parliament with a ceremony, which included the attribution of poetry prizes to students, who won a contest to promote Portuguese learning.

item.title: China and Japan exchange accusations about Diaoyu Islands
item.description: China and Japan accused Sunday of an intrusion on Saturday in the airspace of islands played by the two countries in the East China Sea. The uninhabited islands, known as Diaoyu in China and Senkaku in Japan, are administered by Tokyo but claimed by Beijing, being a point of regular tension between the two countries. Chinese diplomacy announced Sunday that it presented a formal protest to the Japan embassy in Beijing, arguing that "a civil plane entered illegally in airspace around the Diaoyu islands." "The Diaoyu islands and the affiliated islands are a territory belonging to China, and we install Japan immediately ceasing all illegal activities," said Chinese Coast Guard spokesman Liu Dejun. Liu said “a ship-based helicopter” was mobilized to warn and expel the Japanese plane, according to France-Presse (AFP) news agency. Japanese Foreign Deputy Minister Takehiro Funakoshi, in turn, presented a "vigorous protest" to the Chinese ambassador in Tokyo. He cited the "intrusion of four Chinese coastal guard ships in the Japanese territorial waters around the Senkaku islands and the violation of Japanese airspace by a helicopter." According to the Japan Ministry of Defense, the Chinese helicopter invaded Japanese airspace for about 15 minutes. "The [Japanese] self -defense forces reacted by sending fighters," said the ministry, also quoted by AFP. According to Japanese public broadcaster NHK and other local media, it is the first time a helicopter of Chinese authorities violates Japanese airspace on dispute islands. Sides Tensions between China and other countries that claim territories in the Sea of ​​China led Japan to develop ties with the Philippines and the United States. Japanese Prime Minister Shigero Ishiba and Filipino President Ferdinand Marcos agreed on Tuesday to deepen security ties between the two countries. They also agreed to oppose “attempts to alter the 'status quo' in the East China Sea and the southern China Sea by strength or coercion,” in a reference to China.

item.title: Russia | Xi Jinping visiting the country from Wednesday to Saturday
item.description:
The visit of the Chinese president, along with other world leaders such as Lula da Silva, is part of the celebration of the day of victory over Germany Nazi in World War II. Ukraine and the international situation should be on the agenda of the XI meeting with Putin
Russia announced Sunday that Chinese President Xi Jinping will visit the country from Wednesday to Saturday in the 80th anniversary of World War II victory against Germany Nazi, also addressing the Ukrainian conflict. According to a statement issued Sunday by Kremlin and quoted by France-Presse (AFP), Xi Jinping will also participate in bilateral discussions on “the development of world partnership relations and strategic interaction” and “current problems in the order of International and Regional Day”. "It is expected that a series of bilateral documents, between governments and ministries, be signed," added the Kremlin. The visit takes place at a time of commercial confrontation between Beijing and Washington, reaffirming the alliance between Russia and China. In addition to Xi Jinping, leaders from about 20 countries are expected to attend the military parade on May 9 in Red Square, including Brazilian President Lula da Silva and other traditional international allies of Moscow. One of whom is Cuban President Miguel Díaz-Canel, who arrived Sunday in St. Petersburg, where he was received by local governor Alexandr Beglov. Threat exchange On Saturday, Kremlin accused Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky of threatening the celebrations of World War II on May 9 after stating that Kiev could not ensure the safety of international leaders in Moscow. Volodymyr Zelensky “has made an unambiguous threat to world leaders” who will participate in the ceremony, Russian diplomacy spokesman Maria Zakharova said on social networks, according to Russian news agency Tass. Zakharova commented on statements made on Friday night by Zelensky about the celebrations of the 80th anniversary of the victory over Germany Nazi, presided by Vladimir Putin. Zelensky said Kiev could not guarantee the safety of the international leaders present, suggesting that Moscow can do something to blame Ukraine. "We do not know what Russia will do on that date. You can take several measures, such as fires or explosions, and then accuse us," said the Ukrainian President.

item.title: May 1st | Trump prominently in the protests in Asia
item.description: Workers across Asia yesterday marked May 1st with marches and protests that showed the growing discomfort with US President Donald Trump's government and the fear of global economic instability. The holiday, also known as International Workers Day or Labor Day, honors the struggles and achievements of workers and labor movement. In several countries and Asian regions, Trump's agenda was cited as a source of concern. In Taiwan, government leader, Lai Ching-Te, referred to the new tariffs imposed by Trump by promoting a proposal of expenses designed to stabilize the labor market and to support the means of subsistence. In the Philippines, the protest leader, Mong Palatine, warned that “Tariff's wars and policies” threatened local industries. In Japan, there were those who said that Trump's policies hovered on the day as a shadow, according to the US Associated Press (AP) news agency. A Tokyo march truck sported a US president. The demands of participants in the marches in Japan ran from higher wages and gender equality to health care, help in the case of catastrophe, a ceasefire in Gaza and the end of the Russian invasion in Ukraine. "So that our children can live with hope, workers' rights must be recognized," said Junko Kuramochi, a member of a group of mothers in Tokyo. Tadashi Ito, a unionized construction worker, said he was concerned about increasing the prices of imported raw materials. "Everyone is fighting for work, so contracts tend to go where salaries are cheaper," he said, quoted by AP. "We think peace is first. And we hope Trump eradics conflicts and inequalities," he added. Work at risk Under a cloudy sky, about 2,500 trade unionists marched in Taipé, representing sectors ranging from fisheries to telecommunications. Protesters warned that Trump fares can cost jobs in Taiwan. "This is why we hope the government can propose plans to protect workers' rights," said trade union leader Carlos Wang. A car sector workers union showed a cut car with a Trump photograph. In Manila, thousands of Philippine workers marched near the presidential palace, where police blocked access with barricades. Protesters demanded higher wages and greater protection from jobs and local companies. In Indonesia, President Prabowo welcomed thousands of workers who applauded him in the Jakarta National Monument Park. "The government Lidero will work to eliminate Indonesia poverty," the crowd told the crowd. According to the president of the Confederation of Indonesian unions, Said Iqbal, about 200,000 workers will have participated in the May 1st marches in the largest economy in Southeast Asia. In Turkey, the date served not only for labor rights, but also for appeals wider to defend democratic values, as protesters planned to protest against the arrest of the mayor of Istanbul, Ekrem Imamoglu. The arrest of the regime's opponent in March, triggered the country's largest protests in over a decade, and yesterday's holiday offered the prospect of new demonstrations against the government. The authorities blocked access to the center of Istanbul and closed the traffic roads. An association of lawyers stated that more than 200 protesters were arrested near Taksim Square, a long -term meeting point for the concentrations of May 1st.

item.title: PE | China raises sanctions on five MEPs
item.description: China withdrew the sanctions it had applied to five MEPs in March 2021, the European Parliament announced Wednesday. On March 22, 2021, China imposed sanctions on ten individuals and four European Union (EU) entities, including five MEOs and the European Parliament's Human Rights Subcommitte. The sanctions, which prohibited the targets from entering Chinese territory, led the European Parliament to suspend the entire official dialogue with China. In a statement, the European institution announced Wednesday that the five MEOs, which in 2021 they belonged to the sanctioned subcommittee, are no longer covered by the Beijing Sanction regime. Cited in the informative note disclosed, the president of the European Parliament, Roberta Metsola, considered that the MEOs should be able to perform their duties, including "discussing European interests" with China "without fear of any repercussions." "Our relationship with China remains complex and multifaceted. The best way to approach it is through dialogue," said the leader of the European hemiciclo. The announcement of the sanction survey was made to the presidential conference, which includes not only Roberta Metsola, but also the presidents of the political groups represented in the hemicycles of Brussels and Strasbourg.

item.title: Automobile Salon of Shanghai | Manufacturers focused on the international market
item.description: Chinese, German and Japanese auto builders were in the Shanghai Auto Show, indicating that the sector maintains focus on the broader global market and less affected by the heavy tariffs imposed by the United States. There are indications that the 25 percent tariffs on car imports, decreed by US President Donald Trump, are leading companies to reevaluate their strategies-and in some cases discover new opportunities. "When the governments up there are conflict, this ends up affecting the business down," said Ma Lihua, director-general of Soling, a chinese manufacturer of control units and other electronic systems used in components such as gear chambers. Seded in Shanghai, Soling has Ford, Toyota and other major global and Chinese brands among its customers. It is also establishing a production base in Vietname, where the local Vinfost electric vehicle manufacturer aims to become Southeast Asian car leader. Many of the dozens of car parts and components companies present in the hall maintain operations that cross the Chinese market and international markets. Gestamp, producer of metallic components such as chassis and battery boxes, has felt the effects of a slowdown in US and Western European markets, but is expanding in Asia, Latin America and East Europe. North American tariffs have now become another obstacle, at a time when car manufacturers follow the developments closely. "In the past, the supply chains worked like a Swiss clock. Now it's just the opposite," said Ernesto Barcelo, Gestamp's director, about the uncertainty that currently dominates the market. Equated Risks Political stability is a key criterion for investing in any market, Wei Jianjun, president of GWM (Great Wall Motor Co.), told journalists when asked about the company's plans to expand production abroad. This applies to both countries and Hungary-where a decision on the construction of a factory has not yet been made-as well as the US under the presidency of Donald Trump. "If a country is not politically stable, the risk is high," Wei said. With such high rates in the US, GWM is focusing on other markets, such as trade between China and Europe, which is expected to grow, he said. However, it did not comment on rates up to 45.3 percent that the European Union has imposed on electric vehicles manufactured in China. Tianshu Xin, CEO of Leapmotor International-a 'joint venture' between Stellantis and the Chinese Leapmotor-said the North American market is not at this time its priority. “We want to follow the regulatory environment and, in addition, consumer preferences are slightly different from other markets,” said Xin. New investments The Japanese Nissan plans to launch 10 new electric models in China by 2027, of which nine will be of its own brand, and expects to invest another $ 1.4 billion by the end of 2026 to reinforce its presence in the country. In the US, you will be able to use surplus productive capacity to compensate for the reduction of imports caused by tariffs. "Some doors have closed, but others have opened," said Ma. "But any plan to be done will be quickly changed. The market changes very quickly," he noticed. Some of the salon participants believe Trump will eventually moderate his position. "Trump is a businessman and intends to boost the American economy through tariffs on other countries, but I believe these measures are temporary," said Yang Jingdi, assistant to CEO of LVxiang Automobile Parts Co., which manufactures electronic components such as rearview mirrors and pumps. "China has complete and abundant supply chains - and it is the US that won't be able to stand if the tariffs keep both sides," he said.

item.title: Hong Kong | Four Activists released after serving time
item.description: Four pro-democracy activists were released yesterday in Hong Kong, after serving four years and two months, as they participated in unofficial primary elections for the opposition in 2020. Former parliamentarians Claudia Mo, Kwok Ka-Ki, Jeremy Tam and Gary Fan were released during the dawn of three different arrests. The safety operation was significant, with nearby police patrols and access restrictions on several roads before the operation. The release of the dissidents occurred after the court discounted the time since they were detained since the end of February 2021, waiting for trial. After attending in court in March 2021, they were denied their request to leave on bail while awaiting trial for “conspiracy to subvert the power of the State”, according to the National Security Act. According to a new law, passed a year ago, prisoners convicted of national security crimes have to meet more rigorous requirements to ensure early release, which makes their release unlikely. This is the liberation of the first group of 45 Democrats convicted in the largest national security trial in the Chinese semi -autonomous region, completed in November. In an initial decision issued on May 30, the Court of first instance considered the 14 guilty after a long process, which began after Beijing imposed the National Security Act in June 2020.

item.title: HSBC | HSBC profit drops 32% until March
item.description: Banco HSBC, the largest in Europe, yesterday announced profits of $ 6,930 million in the first quarter of the year, in a 32 percent reduction in homologous terms when it had extraordinary gains. According to the results sent yesterday to the Hong Kong Exchange, where it is quoted, the group performed above the analysts' predictions, which anticipated a net result of $ 5,390 million. The reduction of profit in the first three months is explained by the extraordinary impact observed in the same period when sales of the activities in Canada and Argentina. Tax -free, the result fell 25 percent to $ 9,500 million, but was also above the $ 7,830 million estimated by analysts. In turn, the financial margin fell 4.6% percent to $ 8,300 million. Quoted in a statement, HSBC CEO Georges Elhedery considered that the results reflect a “dynamics of gains, discipline in the execution of strategy” and “confidence in the ability to meet objectives”. The bank also warned of “increasing macroeconomic uncertainty” due to commercial tariffs applied by the US executive, led by Donald Trump.

item.title: Álvaro Barbosa, vice-rector of the University of São José: “Student visa is very limiting”
item.description:
The University of São José continues the negotiation saga with the Chinese authorities to recruit students from the interior of China. Vice-rector Álvaro Barbosa expects, soon, the increase in master's students from 30 to 200. Regarding the internationalization of higher education, the official advocates changes in student visas to facilitate recruitment
Does the recruitment of students from the interior of China remain a matter pending to the University of Saint Joseph? It is a process that is underway. We have had huge support from the Macao government in negotiations to obtain the quota for our university, and they have been tireless in the effort to try to resolve the issues raised by the central government. Many of the questions are legitimate and concern concerns that arise. We were granted a temporary quota of 30 students for masters ago over a probative period, which served to evaluate how we, as Western University, would host students from China. From China, there is this concern with the host of students in Macau. I think we have made a huge effort and the students who are there, included in this contingent, are quite satisfied. Is this quota for masters just? Yes. For a degree we do not have authorization yet. In this way, we are currently at the time we try to overcome this probative period in order to obtain a quota of about 200 students for masters. We are in the final phase of the evaluation process and everything has been doing well. We will have the possibility that, next academic year, expand this quota. That would be great, because for our university, to have a greater impact of our mission in Macao, it is essential to have access to students from mainland China. We cannot be a university in an integrated region in a country like China, and not contact with students from China. Is it more difficult for USJ to compete with other universities, such as those of Hong Kong, by foreign students, outside China? The issue of recruitment of international students has become a priority for Macao universities. In the last two or three years, it has become evident that this internationalization is very important. What difficulty is there? There is the issue related to student visas, as these visas currently do not allow students to do any kind of work, denying them that minimum local subsistence mechanism to be able to meet expenses. Nor is it contemplated the possibility of, when the student concludes his formation, to be in the territory and find work. What all countries and regions that are competitive in higher education do, such as Singapore, Hong Kong or Australia, is to have incentive policies. Allow students to work part -time, for example. In Hong Kong when a degree ends, the student can stay in the territory up to a maximum of two years to find a job. This kind of measures do not yet exist in Macau, but I think the government is pondering this possibility. From the moment the decision was made that the internationalization of higher education was important, this must be accompanied with the corresponding measures. The current student visa is extremely limiting and does not encourage the coming to Macao to study, only allows coming. This issue was not as present as it is now, but now there is a strategic policy of internationalization. It is also a matter of survival for local universities. Yes. Perhaps there is no greater example of a catalyst for the diversification of Macau's economy than higher education. We have ten institutions, 60,000 students in about 700,000 inhabitants. This is the potential of internationalization, to foster diversification.
And also the research that comes out of higher education. The investigation, the dynamics of the work that is done. There are a number of vectors that higher education brings to a region or country, this happened to Portugal, for example, with the policy of doctoral scholarships for students from abroad, which completely changed the dynamics of higher education. Cape Verde developed thanks to the impact of higher education. Then we need to make the system more flexible in Macau. I don't know if it's a matter of having a holistic view of strategy. There may be an idea, but then it does not intervene in all the necessary dimensions to achieve a certain goal. But I am very optimistic. I believe this new student policy is a key step to be taken in Macau. The internationalization strategy followed by all these countries and regions I spoke, and were successful in capturing international students, was always the same. No need to invent much. First, one should increase the capacity and notoriety of universities, and then a policy of scholarships, which will enhance a student flow, creating a reference for the territory, so that studying there becomes a habit. After this flow of students for a few years, an image is already created and some scholarships can be removed, which students will continue to choose a particular territory to study in it. Australia has a huge higher education industry, for example, and I think that in Macau we just have to follow the same strategies. We do, at USJ, that a little. How, in concrete terms? We offer many scholarships, and in this sense the Diocese of Macao has helped us build this flow of international students that allow us to create this dynamic that we hope will be sustainable by itself in the future. I think the government is also doing this. There have always been scholarships in Macau, attributed mainly by the Macau Foundation, but this measure will be strengthened. Solving the student's visa issue, creating a scholarship incentive system for five to ten years, Macau will have a bright future as an international higher education destination. But we need to invest, continue, and it takes a few years. USJ created the “Macau Hub” platform, in partnership with the Macau Scientific and Cultural Center (CCCM) in 2023. At what stage is this project? This project has to do with our interest in developing a relationship dynamic of Lusophone countries centered in Lisbon in the area of ​​entrepreneurship, first. This cabinet we have at CCCM is not intended to offer training in Portugal, but we want to do something else. As we are positioned in the Great Bay and with Hengqin, where it is intended to activate a business ecosystem, we want to take advantage of the fact that we have relations with the Lusophone world to activate the access of the startups of Portugal, Brazil and Angola, above all, to the great bay and hengqin. We are trying to create a kind of incubator of transnational companies, in which we support the development of Lusophone businesses that want to settle in the large bay and also the reverse system. Strategically, for a university, it is absolutely fundamental to have a dynamic in the area of ​​entrepreneurship. Currently, more than half of our students do not want to go to the corporate world, but create their own businesses. Just as universities have to have employability solutions, they also have to have them for entrepreneurs, who are increasingly. So a university has to have a business incubator. My vision of the future for higher education goes around: a university, besides having a library and canteen, will also have its own business incubator. I would say that most students of management or economy courses dream of having their own business, especially in China. China is perhaps one of the most entrepreneurial countries in the world. The CCCM welcomes this initiative in Portugal, but we also work with the Portuguese Catholic University. And concrete results, already have it? We have a number of small initial projects that are starting now, and we also work with many business organizations. We have now negotiated a series of projects, and I think everything will develop very quickly, based on the manifestations of interest we have. We were in Angola in December and we have already aligned a series of initiatives, we also have projects with Brazil and Portugal.

item.title: Adelina Moura, teacher and trainer: “The mobile phone is like a Swiss knife”
item.description:
Graduated in the area of ​​educational technologies, Adelina Moura will conduct lectures to parents, students and teachers about the use of digital technologies in classrooms, within the “Letters & Company” festival of the Portuguese Institute of the East. The teacher understands that prohibiting mobile phone in schools is not a solution
What are the challenges felt by teachers with the introduction of technologies in the classroom? Can the mobile phone actually be a complement to learning? Yes. I've been saying this since 2005. The mobile phone can be an excellent learning tool, a means to motivate students and to enrich their learning. We have a kind of Swiss knife here, a very powerful equipment in the hands of the students and there is a school failure, because they do not work and help students enhance this equipment they have. What happens is that students learn in the worst way, in a destructed way, by attempt-rrove. There is a gap, as students are not alerted to the positive potential for mobile phone use. They face their mobile phones as a free time use, spending time on social networks and scrolling, and time consumes. It is essential that teachers are users, in their practices, mobile phones, and for the preparation of classes and other projects, to know how to prepare students. I consider that the school has lost several stages of students' preparation and awareness to use these equipment that lead to classes and with which schools have not spent any money. With the prohibition of bringing the mobile phone to the classroom we did not advance anything in this regard. During the pandemic period, for example, the use of technologies, with distance learning, was quite enhanced. But during the pandemic we also burned some steps regarding the use of digital by teachers, because before the pandemic many teachers did not believe or used. They thought it was a fashion and they saw no use in the use of mobile phones and other technologies. With the pandemic the use of these equipment proved that without them the situation of education would have been much worse. In these pandemic years, teachers have become more aware of the technologies that already exist and are available to anyone. With internet access on mobile phone, something that has existed since 2007 with the launch of the first iPhone, the e-learning system is enhanced and then we move to “Mobile Learning”, where you can learn anywhere and anytime with mobile devices. It is this reality that we see a little away from school. And after the pandemic, how has it been? I think we will take a few more steps towards digital literacy. With Artificial Intelligence (IA), it seems that we are as in the phase I created my first website in 1999 or email in 1995. We are at the beginning. But it is 30 years of technology where there have been many changes, and technology in fact goes on and if we immediately do not realize what we have available, we and students, we help create a moat that has happened in the past compared to digital. In the face of AI, if we do not look back and do not realize what was not done and should have been at school level, we are wasting time. Only a few years from now will people be alert to AI, and the gap is increasing. Hence it is very important to bet now, in this early stage, in the training of teachers, students and families. Is there much ignorance of parents, removal from this reality? We have parents who are from this century. That is, they were born with the existence of computers, internet, saw the appearance of the smartphone. But when they studied, the school did not talk about the potential of digital. So these former students came to society and did not bring this sensitivity to digital, to educate their children. We teachers, when we do digital training, are doing good to society because we are also preparing these young people for the future, because they will be parents and should be aware of educating their children. At school we do not only prepare for the job market, but for personal and family life. Hence teacher education is essential. The invitation I received from IPOR seems to me an excellent holistic view of everything, because the school includes several actors, connecting with society. How should AI be introduced into the classroom? We currently watch changes in search engines, in fact. We have search engines created from root to Age Age, for example. The best way to introduce AI into the classroom is to ask students and how they use it, and already resort to this tool. At the beginning of the academic year I always ask students to answer a questionnaire about their digital routines, and then I know more or less their practices. In 2023, when the chatgPT came out, I introduced AI in my classes, and realized that students were using this tool to deceive the teachers. Students have to realize that when using AI, they are falling into a certain trap because they are not learning. It is the law of the lowest effort, equal to the phase in which the internet emerged, when students selected, copied and sent to the teacher. We now have the problem that the answers are in Brazilian Portuguese, for example, and see as soon as I was used. We have, therefore, to dismantle this action in the heads and face them. I tell them that they are being intellectually dishonest and that they have not read the AI ​​response, for example. Since 2023, I feel that students, in the answers to this questionnaire I do, say they are afraid to use chatgpt because they are afraid of being caught by teachers. That is, it seems to have gained some conscience. It will give these lectures in a different educational context in Asia, where the use of mobile phone can be earlier. How will you deal with these differences, or do you understand that the problems of using technology in the classroom are transversal? It is a transverse question. Do we have to wonder if the use of a particular equipment and tool will make us wiser? It seems to me not, because we may have the equipment, but the use we make it varies a lot. I tell my students that they should be ashamed, because they have much easier access to content than in my time, when we truly had to do research and read in physical format. I tell them that with this technology they should all have a grade 20, and that they are wasting resources, being dishonest intellectually, because they sign works that are not theirs and do not read, even, they deliver. One of the works we have with students is to teach them how to make bibliographic references, refer to the sources. But I am an optimistic by nature, and I hope that in a decade, secondary education students who are fathers and mothers will be able to deal with these problems of social networks and increase fraud with their children. It is this “parents school” that the school can help create. We are in a moment with no return from digital, and forbidding is the most comfortable situation, but it is not the best to face reality. We have to use the right words to alert. We have in this time of alerts and consciences, encouraging the critical spirit of our students, which is little today.
Teach Adelina Moura will teach a workshop for territory teachers on Saturday, with the session “Digital Literacy - Promotion of Positive Interactions”, aimed at teachers and agents of kindergarten, primary and secondary. Degree in Portuguese and French Teaching, Master in Pedagogical Supervision of Portuguese Teaching and Doctorate in Education Sciences, in the Specialty of Educational Technology, Adelina Moura has been developing research in the area of ​​Mobile Learning, with several publications in Portugal and abroad.
